full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Mr. Johnson. How are you feeling today?
Client: I'm a bit nervous, to be honest. Talking about my past experiences at work isn't easy.
Therapist: That's understandable. Remember, you're safe here.

Client: Thank you. I've been thinking about that day a lot since our last session. It was about five years ago, just before I retired. I was working late, trying to finish up a project. My supervisor, Mr. Thompson, came into my office. He'd always been hard on me, but that night was different.
Therapist: You're doing well. Continue.

Client: He started criticizing my work, saying I was too slow, too old to keep up. His voice got louder and louder. I felt trapped, like I couldn't breathe. My hands were shaking so much I could barely type.
Therapist: Stay with that feeling.
Client: It's... it's overwhelming. I can feel my heart racing even now. He kept getting closer, pointing his finger at me, telling me I was worthless, that I should just quit. I wanted to disappear.
Therapist: You're safe here. Keep going.
Client: I... I can't. It's too much.
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You're doing great.

Client: Okay... okay. He knocked over my coffee mug, and it shattered on the floor. The sound made me jump. I remember feeling so small, so helpless. Like I was back in school, being bullied all over again.
Therapist: You're very brave. Continue when you're ready.

Client: I started to cry. I couldn't help it. And that made him even angrier. He said I was pathetic, that I was an embarrassment to the company. I wanted to stand up for myself, but I couldn't find the words. My throat felt tight, like I was choking.
Therapist: It's okay to feel these emotions.
Client: I just sat there, frozen, until he finally left. But even after he was gone, I could still hear his voice in my head. I felt so ashamed, so worthless. I couldn't stop shaking for hours.
Therapist: You're handling this well. Keep going.

Client: The next day, I called in sick. I couldn't face going back there. I was afraid of seeing him, afraid of what he might say or do. I felt like a coward, but I just couldn't do it. I ended up retiring early because of that incident. I've never told anyone about this before.
Therapist: Thank you for sharing. How do you feel now?
Client: Exhausted, but... also a bit relieved. It's like a weight has been lifted, you know? I've carried this for so long.
Therapist: That's a normal reaction. You've done well today.
Client: Thank you. I didn't think I could talk about it, but somehow, it feels a little easier now. Is that strange?
Therapist: Not at all. It's a positive sign.
Client: I still feel angry though. Angry at Mr. Thompson, but also at myself for not standing up to him. I wish I had done something, said something.
Therapist: Those feelings are valid.
Client: I keep wondering if I could have prevented it somehow. If I had worked faster, or stayed later, or... I don't know. Maybe it wouldn't have happened.
Therapist: Remember, it wasn't your fault.

Client: I know that logically, but emotionally... it's hard to accept. I still have nightmares sometimes. I dream that I'm back in that office, and he's there, but this time I can't move at all. I wake up in a cold sweat.
Therapist: That's a common response to trauma.
Client: Will it ever go away? This feeling of... of being less than? Of not being good enough?
Therapist: With time and work, it can improve.
Client: I hope so. I'm tired of feeling this way. Sometimes I think about having a drink to numb it all, but I know that's not the answer. I've worked too hard to stay sober.
Therapist: You're making good choices.
Client: Thank you. It's not easy, but I'm trying. I want to move past this, to not let it control me anymore. But it's hard when those memories come flooding back.
Therapist: You're showing great strength.

Client: I appreciate that. I just... I want to be able to think about my career without this incident overshadowing everything. I had good times too, you know? But this one night seems to have tainted it all.
Therapist: That's a common feeling. We'll work on that.
Client: I hope we can. I want to be able to look back on my life with pride, not shame. I want to feel like I accomplished something, that I mattered.
Therapist: You do matter. We'll end here for today.
Client: Thank you, Doctor. This was difficult, but I'm glad we did it. Same time next week?
Therapist: Yes, see you then. Take care.
